cards.back: Service-public.fr explique le TAEG. Réf: https://www.service-public.gouv.fr/particuliers/vosdroits/F2456

cards.front: Où trouver une ressource fiable sur le coût total du crédit ?
cards.back: La finance pour tous: coût total du crédit. Réf: https://www.lafinancepourtous.com/pratique/credit/souscrire-un-credit/combien-coute-votre-emprunt/le-cout-total-du-credit/

cards.front: Où trouver une ressource fiable sur le taux d’usure ?
cards.back: Banque de France explique le taux d’usure. Réf: https://www.banque-france.fr/fr/a-votre-service/particuliers/connaitre-pratiques-bancaires-assurance/credit/taux-usure

cards.front: Où trouver des infos officielles sur le surendettement ?
cards.back: Banque de France: dossier de surendettement. Réf: https://www.banque-france.fr/fr/a-votre-service/particuliers/dossier-surendettement

cards.front: Quelle ressource de l’État décrit les PCB ?
cards.back: Réf: https://solidarites.gouv.fr/point-conseil-budget-pcb

cards.front: Qu’est-ce qu’un taux fixe vs taux variable (idée) ?
cards.back: Taux fixe: constant. Taux variable: évolue selon un indice, donc incertitude sur la mensualité/coût.

cards.front: Pourquoi une assurance emprunteur peut peser dans le TAEG ?
cards.back: Si elle est obligatoire, son coût s’ajoute au crédit et augmente le TAEG.

cards.front: Qu’est-ce qu’un “différé” sur un prêt étudiant ?
cards.back: Une période où tu ne rembourses pas (ou seulement intérêts) avant le remboursement complet.

cards.front: Pourquoi le découvert peut déclencher une spirale ?
cards.back: Frais + agios + nouvelles dépenses: tu compensses en t’endettant davantage.

cards.front: Qu’est-ce qu’un tableau d’amortissement montre en 1 phrase ?
cards.back: Comment chaque mensualité se répartit entre intérêts et capital, et comment le capital restant dû baisse.

cards.front: Quel piège fréquent avec une mensualité “faible” ?
cards.back: Une durée plus longue et un coût total plus élevé (plus d’intérêts sur la durée).

cards.front: Pourquoi comparer 2 offres avec le TAEG et le coût total ?
cards.back: Parce que taux nominal seul ne suffit pas; frais et assurance changent la facture.
Fusionner plusieurs crédits en un seul; à évaluer via TAEG et coût total.

cards.back: La finance pour tous: dictionnaire. Réf: https://www.lafinancepourtous.com/outils/dictionnaire/tableau-damortissement/
La part des revenus consacrée aux remboursements; trop élevée rend le budget fragile.

cards.front: Quelle priorité en cas de difficulté ?
cards.back: Stabiliser l’essentiel (logement/énergie), stopper les frais, contacter les créanciers et chercher un accompagnement.

cards.front: Que fait la Banque de France dans la procédure de surendettement ?
cards.back: Elle reçoit le dossier et assure le secrétariat de la commission, qui propose des solutions adaptées.

cards.back: Réf: https://www.lafinancepourtous.com/pratique/credit/souscrire-un-credit/combien-coute-votre-emprunt/le-cout-total-du-credit/

sampleIdeas.name: TAEG: le chiffre #1 pour comparer un crédit
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le TAEG (taux annuel effectif global) mesure le coût réel d’un prêt en incluant le taux nominal et les frais obligatoires. C’est l’outil le plus utile pour comparer deux offres.

Deux prêts au même taux nominal peuvent coûter différemment si les frais et l’assurance changent. Le TAEG rend cette différence visible.

Bon réflexe: demander le TAEG, le coût total en euros et un tableau d’amortissement.

En cas de doute, vérifie les définitions sur Service-public.

sampleIdeas.name: Coût total du crédit: comprendre la “facture”
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le coût total du crédit est la somme payée en plus du capital emprunté (intérêts + frais). Beaucoup de gens se focalisent sur la mensualité, mais c’est le coût total qui révèle la facture.

Allonger la durée baisse la mensualité, mais augmente souvent le coût total.

Un bon choix cherche un équilibre entre soutenabilité et coût.

La finance pour tous explique cette notion avec des exemples.

sampleIdeas.name: Tableau d’amortissement: intérêts vs capital
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le tableau d’amortissement détaille chaque mensualité: intérêts, capital, restant dû. Au début, la part d’intérêts est plus élevée car le capital est important.

Comprendre ce tableau aide à voir l’impact d’un remboursement anticipé.

C’est aussi un outil de comparaison entre offres.

Entraîne-toi à lire les 3 colonnes clés: intérêts, capital, restant dû.

sampleIdeas.name: Taux d’usure: plafond légal et lien avec le TAEG
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le taux d’usure est un taux plafond légal: aucun crédit ne peut être accordé au-delà de ce TAEG maximal. Il protège l’emprunteur.

Ce qui compte est le TAEG “tout compris” (assurance/frais inclus si obligatoires).

La Banque de France explique le mécanisme et publie des repères.

Si une offre te paraît confuse, reviens au trio: TAEG, coût total, amortissement.

sampleIdeas.name: Surendettement: agir tôt et se faire accompagner
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le surendettement est souvent une accumulation: découvert, retards, frais, puis nouveaux crédits pour “tenir”. Le meilleur levier est d’agir tôt.

En France, la procédure est gratuite et gérée par la Banque de France. Des Points conseil budget (PCB) peuvent aussi accompagner.

Même si tu n’es pas “au pire”, un accompagnement peut aider à reconstruire un budget soutenable.

Règle pratique: plus tu attends, plus les frais et le stress augmentent.

sampleIdeas.name: Stratégies de remboursement: avalanche vs boule de neige
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Avalanche: tu attaques la dette au taux le plus élevé (optimal pour réduire les intérêts). Boule de neige: tu rembourses d’abord la plus petite dette (effet motivation).

Dans les deux cas: payer les minimums sur toutes les dettes, puis mettre tout le surplus sur la priorité.

Choisis la méthode que tu tiendras dans la durée.

Le plus important est la constance et d’éviter de nouvelles dettes coûteuses.

sampleIdeas.name: Comparer une offre de crédit: la méthode “TAEG + coût total”
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Comparer deux crédits est plus simple qu’il n’y paraît: commence par le TAEG (coût tout compris), puis regarde le coût total en euros.

Ensuite, vérifie la durée et la mensualité: une mensualité plus basse peut cacher un coût total plus élevé.

Demande aussi le tableau d’amortissement: tu verras l’évolution intérêts/capital.

Ce cadre évite les décisions émotionnelles ou sous pression.

sampleIdeas.name: Découvert et frais: pourquoi ça s’emballe vite
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le découvert semble “petit”, mais les frais et agios peuvent s’accumuler, surtout quand tu passes d’un découvert à un autre.

Le risque est la spirale: frais → budget plus serré → nouveau découvert.

Le plan de sortie: budget minimal, stopper les dépenses variables non essentielles temporairement, et construire un buffer.

Si tu bloques, un accompagnement type PCB peut aider à remettre un plan en place.

sampleIdeas.name: Prêt étudiant: vérifier le différé, la durée et le coût
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Avant de signer un prêt étudiant, vérifie: TAEG, durée, et existence d’un différé (aucun paiement ou paiement réduit au début).

Simule une mensualité réaliste après études en tenant compte du logement et des dépenses essentielles.

Compare au moins deux offres et regarde le coût total: c’est souvent la donnée la plus parlante.

Réduire le montant emprunté diminue le risque (bourses, job, dépenses).

sampleIdeas.name: Taux d’usure: ressource État et vocabulaire clé
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le taux d’usure est un plafond légal: au-delà, un crédit ne peut pas être accordé. Le point important est que l’on parle du TAEG, c’est-à-dire du coût “tout compris”.

Quand les taux bougent, l’assurance et les frais peuvent faire dépasser le plafond même si le taux nominal semble “raisonnable”.

Savoir lire ces mots (TAEG, coût total, assurance, amortissement) te donne le contrôle.

Economie.gouv propose une explication de référence sur le sujet.

name: Human Body & Energy Basics
description: Core science-based principles of energy balance, muscle growth, sleep, stress, and physical activity.

cards.front: What is energy balance in the human body?
cards.back: Energy balance is the relationship between calories consumed and calories expended, determining weight gain, loss, or maintenance.

cards.front: What happens when calorie intake exceeds expenditure?
cards.back: The excess energy is stored in the body, primarily as fat tissue.

cards.front: What happens when calorie expenditure exceeds intake?
cards.back: The body uses stored energy, leading to weight loss over time.
BMR is the energy the body uses at rest to maintain vital functions like breathing and circulation.
Body size, muscle mass, age, sex, and genetics influence basal metabolic rate.
Muscle hypertrophy is the increase in muscle fiber size due to resistance training and adequate nutrition.
Mechanical tension from resistance training combined with sufficient recovery triggers muscle growth.

cards.front: Why is protein important for muscle growth?
cards.back: Protein provides amino acids needed to repair and build muscle tissue after training.

cards.front: Does muscle turn into fat when you stop training?
cards.back: No. Muscle and fat are different tissues; muscle may shrink while fat increases if energy intake is high.
Cardiovascular fitness is the ability of the heart, lungs, and blood vessels to deliver oxygen during sustained activity.

cards.front: What role does sleep play in health?
cards.back: Sleep supports recovery, hormone regulation, immune function, and cognitive performance.
The body prioritizes physical recovery, tissue repair, and hormone release.

cards.front: What is stress from a physiological perspective?
cards.back: Stress is the body’s response to perceived demands, involving hormones like cortisol and adrenaline.
No. Cortisol is essential for energy regulation and stress response, but chronic elevation can be harmful.
VO₂ max is the maximum rate at which the body can use oxygen during intense exercise.
Metabolic adaptation is a reduction in energy expenditure in response to prolonged calorie restriction.
No. Fat loss occurs systemically, not from targeted body areas.
Insulin helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream for energy or storage.

cards.front: Why is regular physical activity important?
cards.back: It improves cardiovascular health, metabolic function, mental health, and longevity.

cards.front: What organization sets global physical activity guidelines?
cards.back: The World Health Organization (WHO).

sampleIdeas.name: Energy Balance Explained
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Energy balance is a fundamental concept in human physiology. When energy intake equals energy expenditure, body weight tends to remain stable.

A sustained surplus leads to energy storage, mainly as fat, while a sustained deficit leads to weight loss. This principle holds regardless of diet style.

Short-term fluctuations are normal due to water balance and glycogen storage.

Understanding energy balance helps cut through many weight-loss myths.

sampleIdeas.name: How Muscles Grow
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Muscle growth occurs when resistance training creates mechanical stress on muscle fibers. This triggers repair processes that rebuild fibers slightly thicker.

Adequate protein intake and rest are required for this adaptation to occur.

Without training stimulus, muscle size can decrease, but it does not convert into fat.

This process is well established in exercise physiology.

sampleIdeas.name: Sleep and Recovery
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Sleep is essential for physical and mental health. During deep sleep, the body repairs tissues and regulates hormones.

Chronic sleep deprivation is associated with metabolic disorders, impaired cognition, and increased disease risk.

Both duration and quality of sleep matter.

Adults are generally advised to sleep 7–9 hours per night.

sampleIdeas.name: Stress Physiology
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Stress activates hormonal systems that help the body respond to challenges. Short-term stress can be adaptive.

Problems arise when stress is chronic and recovery is insufficient.

Managing stress supports both physical and mental health.

Exercise, sleep, and social support play protective roles.

sampleIdeas.name: Physical Activity Guidelines
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Regular physical activity reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and depression.

The WHO recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate activity per week for adults.

Both aerobic exercise and strength training are important.

Consistency matters more than intensity.

name: Nutrition Science Basics
description: Evidence-based nutrition principles: macronutrients, fiber, hydration, labels, and supplements.

cards.back: Macronutrients are nutrients needed in large amounts: carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

cards.front: What is the primary role of carbohydrates?
cards.back: Carbohydrates are a major energy source for the body, especially during high-intensity activity.

cards.front: What is the primary role of dietary protein?
cards.back: Protein supports tissue repair, muscle maintenance, and enzyme and hormone production.

cards.front: What is the primary role of dietary fats?
cards.back: Fats support hormone production, nutrient absorption, and long-term energy storage.
Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals needed in small amounts for normal body function.
Fiber supports digestive health, blood sugar control, and cardiovascular health.
Energy density refers to calories per gram of food.
No. The liver and kidneys already detoxify the body effectively.

cards.front: What does a nutrition label primarily show?
cards.back: It shows energy content, macronutrients, and key micronutrients per serving.
No. Excess intake can be harmful, but sugar itself is not toxic in normal amounts.
Hydration supports circulation, temperature regulation, and cellular function.

cards.front: Do supplements replace a balanced diet?
cards.back: No. Supplements can address deficiencies but do not replace whole foods.

cards.front: What organization provides global nutrition guidance?
cards.back: The World Health Organization (WHO).

sampleIdeas.name: Macronutrients Without Myths
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Macronutrients provide energy and structural components for the body. Each plays a distinct role.

No macronutrient is inherently harmful; problems arise from imbalance or excess.

Balanced diets can take many forms depending on culture and preference.

Scientific consensus emphasizes overall dietary patterns over single nutrients.

sampleIdeas.name: Fiber and Long-Term Health
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Dietary fiber supports gut health and is associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular disease.

Many populations consume less fiber than recommended.

Fiber-rich foods include fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains.

Increasing fiber intake gradually helps avoid digestive discomfort.

sampleIdeas.name: Supplements: What They Can and Can’t Do
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Supplements can be useful for specific deficiencies or life stages.

They are not a substitute for a varied diet.

Excessive supplementation can be harmful.

Evidence-based use is recommended.

sampleIdeas.name: Hydration and Performance
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Water is essential for circulation, temperature regulation, and nutrient transport.

Most healthy adults can rely on thirst and normal meals for hydration.

Extreme hydration claims are not supported by evidence.

Needs vary with activity and environment.

sampleIdeas.name: Reading Nutrition Labels
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Nutrition labels help compare foods by energy and nutrient content.

Serving size context is critical.

Labels support informed choices but don’t determine diet quality alone.

Whole dietary patterns matter most.

name: Corps Humain & Énergie
description: Principes scientifiques du bilan énergétique, du muscle, du sommeil, du stress et de l’activité physique.

cards.front: Qu’est-ce que le bilan énergétique du corps humain ?
cards.back: Le bilan énergétique compare les calories consommées et dépensées, déterminant prise, perte ou maintien du poids.

cards.front: Que se passe-t-il en cas d’excédent calorique ?
cards.back: L’excès d’énergie est stocké par l’organisme, principalement sous forme de masse grasse.

cards.front: Que se passe-t-il en cas de déficit calorique ?
cards.back: Le corps utilise ses réserves d’énergie, ce qui conduit à une perte de poids dans le temps.

cards.front: Qu’est-ce que le métabolisme de base (MB) ?
cards.back: Le métabolisme de base correspond à l’énergie dépensée au repos pour maintenir les fonctions vitales.

cards.front: Quels facteurs influencent le métabolisme de base ?
cards.back: La masse corporelle, la masse musculaire, l’âge, le sexe et la génétique.
L’augmentation de la taille des fibres musculaires en réponse à un entraînement de résistance.

cards.front: Quel stimulus déclenche la croissance musculaire ?
cards.back: La tension mécanique créée par l’entraînement associée à une récupération suffisante.
Elles fournissent les acides aminés nécessaires à la réparation et à la construction des tissus.

cards.front: Les muscles se transforment-ils en graisse ?
cards.back: Non. Les muscles et la graisse sont des tissus distincts ; ils ne se transforment pas l’un en l’autre.
La capacité du cœur et des poumons à fournir de l’oxygène pendant un effort prolongé.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle du sommeil dans la santé ?
cards.back: Le sommeil soutient la récupération, l’immunité, la régulation hormonale et les fonctions cognitives.

cards.front: Que se passe-t-il pendant le sommeil profond ?
cards.back: L’organisme privilégie la réparation des tissus et la libération d’hormones.

cards.front: Qu’est-ce que le stress sur le plan physiologique ?
cards.back: Une réponse hormonale de l’organisme à une demande perçue, impliquant notamment le cortisol.
Non. Il est nécessaire à l’adaptation au stress, mais devient problématique s’il est chroniquement élevé.
La capacité maximale du corps à utiliser l’oxygène lors d’un effort intense.
Une baisse des dépenses énergétiques lors d’une restriction calorique prolongée.

cards.front: Peut-on perdre de la graisse localement ?
cards.back: Non. La perte de graisse est globale et non ciblée sur une zone précise.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle principal de l’insuline ?
cards.back: Permettre aux cellules d’absorber le glucose sanguin pour l’énergie ou le stockage.

cards.front: Pourquoi l’activité physique régulière est-elle essentielle ?
cards.back: Elle réduit les risques cardiovasculaires, améliore le métabolisme et la santé mentale.

cards.front: Quelle organisation publie les recommandations mondiales d’activité physique ?
cards.back: L’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS).

sampleIdeas.name: Comprendre le bilan énergétique
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le bilan énergétique est un principe fondamental de la physiologie humaine. Lorsque les apports énergétiques égalent les dépenses, le poids corporel tend à rester stable.

Un excédent prolongé entraîne un stockage d’énergie, tandis qu’un déficit conduit à l’utilisation des réserves.

Des variations à court terme sont normales et liées à l’eau et au glycogène.

Ce principe permet de déconstruire de nombreux mythes sur la perte de poids.

sampleIdeas.name: Comment les muscles se développent
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
La croissance musculaire résulte d’un stress mécanique appliqué aux fibres lors de l’entraînement.

La récupération et un apport protéique suffisant sont indispensables à cette adaptation.

En l’absence de stimulus, le muscle peut diminuer, sans se transformer en graisse.

Ces mécanismes sont bien établis en physiologie de l’exercice.

sampleIdeas.name: Sommeil et récupération
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le sommeil est essentiel à la santé globale. Il permet la réparation des tissus et la régulation hormonale.

Un manque chronique de sommeil est associé à des troubles métaboliques et cognitifs.

La durée et la qualité du sommeil sont toutes deux importantes.

Chez l’adulte, 7 à 9 heures sont généralement recommandées.

sampleIdeas.name: Physiologie du stress
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le stress active des systèmes hormonaux permettant de faire face à une situation.

À court terme, il peut être bénéfique, mais un stress chronique nuit à la santé.

La récupération, le sommeil et l’activité physique aident à réguler cette réponse.

Une gestion adaptée du stress soutient la santé à long terme.

sampleIdeas.name: Recommandations d’activité physique
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
L’activité physique régulière réduit les risques de maladies chroniques.

L’OMS recommande au moins 150 minutes d’activité modérée par semaine chez l’adulte.

Les exercices d’endurance et de renforcement sont complémentaires.

La régularité prime sur l’intensité.

name: Nutrition : bases scientifiques
description: Principes nutritionnels fondés sur la science : macronutriments, fibres, hydratation et étiquettes.

cards.back: Les nutriments nécessaires en grande quantité : glucides, protéines et lipides.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle principal des glucides ?
cards.back: Fournir de l’énergie, en particulier lors des efforts intenses.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle principal des protéines ?
cards.back: Participer à la réparation des tissus et à la production d’enzymes et d’hormones.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle principal des lipides ?
cards.back: Soutenir la production hormonale et l’absorption de certaines vitamines.
Les vitamines et minéraux nécessaires en petites quantités.
Elles favorisent la santé digestive et cardiovasculaire.
Le nombre de calories par gramme d’aliment.

cards.front: Les cures détox éliminent-elles les toxines ?
cards.back: Non. Le foie et les reins assurent naturellement la détoxification.

cards.front: Que montrent principalement les étiquettes nutritionnelles ?
cards.back: L’énergie, les macronutriments et certains micronutriments par portion.
Non. C’est l’excès chronique qui peut être problématique.

cards.front: Quel est le rôle principal de l’hydratation ?
cards.back: Maintenir la circulation, la température et les fonctions cellulaires.

cards.front: Les compléments remplacent-ils une alimentation équilibrée ?
cards.back: Non. Ils peuvent corriger des carences mais ne remplacent pas les aliments.

cards.front: Quelle organisation publie les recommandations nutritionnelles mondiales ?
cards.back: L’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS).

sampleIdeas.name: Macronutriments sans idées reçues
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Les macronutriments fournissent l’énergie et les matériaux nécessaires au corps.

Aucun macronutriment n’est intrinsèquement nocif.

Les déséquilibres prolongés sont plus importants que la présence d’un nutriment spécifique.

Les recommandations portent sur l’ensemble du régime alimentaire.

sampleIdeas.name: Fibres et santé à long terme
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Les fibres alimentaires soutiennent le microbiote intestinal.

Elles sont associées à une réduction des risques cardiovasculaires.

Les apports sont souvent insuffisants dans les régimes modernes.

Les fruits, légumes et céréales complètes sont des sources clés.

sampleIdeas.name: Compléments alimentaires : utilité et limites
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Les compléments peuvent être utiles dans des situations précises.

Ils ne remplacent pas une alimentation variée.

Un excès peut être nocif.

Les recommandations officielles privilégient l’alimentation.

sampleIdeas.name: Hydratation et fonctions corporelles
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
L’eau est essentielle à la régulation thermique et au transport des nutriments.

Chez l’adulte sain, la soif est un bon indicateur.

Les besoins varient selon l’activité et le climat.

Les discours extrêmes ne sont pas soutenus scientifiquement.

sampleIdeas.name: Lire une étiquette nutritionnelle
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Les étiquettes permettent de comparer les produits.

La taille de portion est essentielle pour l’interprétation.

Elles ne suffisent pas à juger la qualité globale d’un régime.

Les choix alimentaires s’inscrivent dans un ensemble.

name: Reasoning With Data (Science Literacy)
description: Practical scientific reasoning: bias, base rates, risk, and how to interpret data-driven claims.

cards.back: The underlying prevalence of an event in a population before new evidence.

cards.front: Why do base rates matter in medical testing?
cards.back: Low prevalence can make false positives outnumber true positives even with good tests.
Probability a test is positive given the condition is present.
Probability a test is negative given the condition is absent.
A test indicates the condition when it is not actually present.
A test misses a condition that is present.

cards.front: What is a confounder (again, in one line)?
cards.back: A third variable that distorts the apparent relationship between two variables.
Bias from how participants are selected into a study or sample.
Focusing on “survivors” and ignoring cases that disappeared, skewing conclusions.

cards.front: What is regression to the mean?
cards.back: Extreme results tend to be followed by more typical results due to randomness.
A model captures noise in training data, reducing performance on new data.
A credible “how” that connects cause to effect consistent with known science.
A pattern where changing exposure changes the effect in a consistent direction.

cards.front: What is a randomized controlled trial (RCT)?
cards.back: A study where participants are randomly assigned to treatment or control groups.
Analyzing participants in their assigned groups, preserving randomization benefits.

cards.front: What is a “statistical vs practical” difference?
cards.back: A result can be statistically detectable but too small to matter in real life.
How many people need treatment to prevent one additional bad outcome.
Risk in one group divided by risk in another.
The difference in risk between groups, not a ratio.

cards.front: What is a confidence interval used for?
cards.back: To express uncertainty around an estimate instead of a single number.

sampleIdeas.name: Base rates and false positives (Bayes intuition)
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A test can look “accurate” but still produce many false positives when the condition is rare.

Base rates are the missing piece: prevalence affects how to interpret a positive result.

Bayes’ rule formalizes this update, but the intuition is enough: always ask “how common is it?”

This helps you interpret medical headlines responsibly.

sampleIdeas.name: Bias catalog: the usual ways we fool ourselves
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Selection bias, survivorship bias, and confirmation bias are common failure modes.

They can make strong narratives from weak evidence.

A simple defense is to ask what data are missing, and how the sample was chosen.

Bias awareness is a learnable skill.

sampleIdeas.name: Effect sizes: why “how much” matters
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Scientific results should answer “how much” and “with what uncertainty.”

Effect size tells magnitude. Confidence intervals show uncertainty.

A tiny effect may be statistically significant in huge samples, but irrelevant in practice.

This prevents overreacting to weak effects.

sampleIdeas.name: Causal reasoning checklist
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
For causal claims, look for: temporality (cause before effect), dose-response, plausible mechanism, and consistency across studies.

Randomized trials are strongest, but not always possible.

When only observational data exist, be cautious.

This checklist upgrades everyday reasoning.

sampleIdeas.name: Reading risk numbers in the news
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Relative risk can sound dramatic, but absolute risk is what you experience.

Ask for base rates and absolute changes.

Use NNT when available: it translates risk into something tangible.

This is essential health and science literacy.

name: Scientific Method & Evidence
description: How science builds reliable knowledge: hypotheses, study design, bias, replication, and interpreting results.

cards.front: What is the goal of the scientific method?
cards.back: To build reliable knowledge by testing explanations against observations and evidence.
A testable proposed explanation or prediction about a phenomenon.

cards.front: What is a theory in science?
cards.back: A well-supported explanatory framework that integrates many observations and tests.
A descriptive statement about what happens, often expressed mathematically, without necessarily explaining why.
A claim is falsifiable if evidence could, in principle, show it to be wrong.
An experiment where variables are controlled so the effect of one variable can be isolated.
A factor related to both the supposed cause and effect that can bias results.
To reduce systematic bias by assigning groups by chance.
An inactive treatment used to compare against an active intervention.
Keeping participants and/or researchers unaware of group assignments to reduce bias.
Repeating studies or experiments to see if results are consistent.
Expert evaluation of research before publication to assess quality and plausibility.

cards.front: What is the difference between correlation and causation?
cards.back: Correlation is association; causation means one variable produces changes in the other.
A methodical synthesis of evidence from multiple studies using defined criteria.
A statistical method combining results from multiple studies to estimate an overall effect.
A measure of how large an effect is, not just whether it exists.
The probability a study will detect a real effect if it exists.
The tendency for positive results to be published more often than negative/null results.
A research paper shared publicly before peer review.
Whether the same analysis can be rerun to get the same results using the same data and code.

cards.front: What does “extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence” mean?
cards.back: Claims far from established knowledge require stronger, more rigorous evidence.

cards.front: What is the burden of proof?
cards.back: The responsibility to provide evidence lies with the person making the claim.
A default statement that there is no effect or difference, used in hypothesis tests.
How surprising the data are under the null hypothesis.
A range of plausible values for a parameter based on sample data.

cards.front: What is a sample size trade-off?
cards.back: Larger samples reduce random error but cost more time/money.
Selecting only supportive examples while ignoring contrary data.
An explanation describing the process that produces an effect (how it works).
Uncertainty that comes from simplifications or assumptions in a model.
Hazard is potential harm; risk is likelihood of harm given exposure.

cards.front: What is absolute risk vs relative risk?
cards.back: Absolute risk is actual probability; relative risk compares probabilities between groups.

sampleIdeas.name: Correlation vs causation: the confounder problem
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Correlation is common because many variables move together. The hard question is whether one causes the other.

Confounders can create correlations: a third factor influences both variables.

Strong causal claims usually need randomized experiments or careful quasi-experimental designs.

This single skill protects you from a huge share of misinformation.

sampleIdeas.name: Study design ladder: from anecdotes to trials
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Not all evidence is equal. Anecdotes are compelling but unreliable. Observational studies can suggest associations but are vulnerable to confounding.

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) reduce bias by random assignment. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses summarize multiple studies.

Learn to ask: Who was studied? How were groups formed? What was measured?

This is scientific literacy in practice.

sampleIdeas.name: Replication and reproducibility
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Replication asks: do we see the same result again with new data? Reproducibility asks: can we rerun the analysis and get the same numbers?

Both matter. Transparent methods, shared data, and code improve reliability.

Single studies are rarely definitive. Patterns across multiple studies are stronger.

Treat science as a process, not a set of isolated papers.

sampleIdeas.name: p-values, confidence intervals, and effect sizes
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A p-value is about “surprise under the null,” not “probability the hypothesis is true.”

Confidence intervals show uncertainty and help interpret practical importance.

Effect size answers the real question: how big is the impact?

Good scientific communication reports all three, plus limitations.

sampleIdeas.name: How to read a science headline
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Start with the claim: what exactly is being asserted? Then ask: what evidence supports it, and what is the study design?

Look for absolute numbers, not just relative changes. Ask whether the effect is large enough to matter.

Check for conflicts of interest and whether the result has been replicated.

If the headline outruns the data, be skeptical.

name: Cybersecurity & Privacy Essentials
description: Practical security habits: passwords, MFA, phishing, updates, backups, and privacy basics.

cards.front: What is a strong password strategy?
cards.back: Use long, unique passwords for every account, stored in a password manager.
Using stolen username/password pairs to try logging into many sites.
Authentication using two or more factors (knowledge, possession, inherence).
A weakness in software that attackers can exploit.
Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption.
Manipulating people into revealing information or taking unsafe actions.

cards.front: What is a privacy setting good for?
cards.back: Controlling what data is collected, shared, or visible to others.
Unauthorized access to and exposure of stored data.
Grant only the minimum permissions needed.

cards.front: What is a secure update habit?
cards.back: Enable automatic updates for OS/apps to get security patches quickly.
Data stored on disk is encrypted to prevent readable theft if accessed.
Data is encrypted while being sent over networks (e.g., TLS).
A tool that encrypts traffic to a VPN server, reducing local network snooping but not guaranteeing anonymity.

cards.front: What is a browser extension risk?
cards.back: Extensions can access browsing data; malicious ones can steal info.

cards.front: What is a permission red flag on mobile?
cards.back: An app requesting access unrelated to its purpose (e.g., flashlight asking contacts).
Keep 3 copies of data, on 2 different media, with 1 offsite.

cards.front: What is a secure Wi‑Fi practice?
cards.back: Avoid sensitive logins on unknown networks; use HTTPS and consider a VPN.
A public key can be shared to encrypt/verify; a private key is kept secret to decrypt/sign.
The trail of data you leave through online activity and accounts.

cards.front: What should you do after a suspected account compromise?
cards.back: Change password, enable MFA, log out sessions, and review recovery options/alerts.

sampleIdeas.name: Threat model: security that matches your life
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Security is about reducing realistic risk. Your threat model depends on what you’re protecting and from whom.

Start with high-impact basics: unique passwords, MFA, and updates.

Then add backups and account recovery planning.

This approach avoids security theater and focuses on what matters.

sampleIdeas.name: Phishing and social engineering: the #1 entry point
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Most breaches start with people, not code. Attackers exploit urgency, authority, and curiosity.

Train yourself to verify independently and slow down.

Treat one-time codes as highly sensitive.

Good habits beat complex tools.

sampleIdeas.name: Backups and ransomware resilience
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Backups are the best defense against ransomware and accidental loss.

Use the 3-2-1 rule and test restores.

Separate backups from always-connected drives.

Resilience is a system, not a single tool.

sampleIdeas.name: Permissions and least privilege on phones
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Apps often request more access than they need. Limiting permissions reduces what can be leaked.

Regularly review camera, microphone, location, and contacts access.

Prefer “only while using” for location.

Less data exposure means less damage if something goes wrong.

sampleIdeas.name: Encryption: what it protects (and what it doesn’t)
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Encryption protects confidentiality, but doesn’t automatically guarantee safety from scams or account takeovers.

HTTPS protects traffic in transit; device encryption protects stored data.

End-to-end encryption prevents service providers from reading message content.

Know the limits so you don’t develop a false sense of security.

name: Digital Basics: Internet & Web
description: Internet and web fundamentals: HTTP/HTTPS, DNS, URLs, browsers, cookies, and basic online safety.

cards.front: What is the Internet (in one sentence)?
cards.back: A global network of networks that routes data between devices using standardized protocols.

cards.front: What is the World Wide Web?
cards.back: A system of interlinked documents and apps accessed over the Internet via HTTP and URLs.
A protocol that defines how web clients and servers request and deliver resources.
HTTP with encryption and authentication using TLS.
An address that specifies how to access a resource on the web.
A system that translates domain names (like example.com) into IP addresses.
A numerical identifier for a device on a network used for routing data.
Software that retrieves and displays web content (HTML, CSS, JS).
Small data stored by a site in your browser to remember state or track behavior.
Browser storage that lets sites store data on your device beyond a session.
Code that collects behavior data across sites or apps for analytics/ads.
A login method requiring two factors, like password plus a code or device prompt.
A scam that tricks you into revealing data or installing malware by impersonating a trusted source.
Malicious software designed to damage, disrupt, or steal information.
A tool that generates, stores, and autofills strong unique passwords.
Transforming information so only authorized parties can read it.
Only sender and recipient can read messages; intermediaries cannot.
A setting controlling what device data/features an app can access (camera, location).
Give apps/users only the access needed to do their job, nothing more.

cards.front: What is a software update important for?
cards.back: Updates often patch security vulnerabilities and fix bugs.

sampleIdeas.name: Internet vs Web: the essential distinction
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The Internet is the underlying network infrastructure: routers, cables, IP addresses, and protocols.

The Web is one application on top of the Internet: web pages and apps accessed via HTTP/HTTPS.

Mixing these up creates confusion when troubleshooting or learning.

Once you separate “network” from “application,” everything becomes clearer.

sampleIdeas.name: DNS and URLs: how your browser finds a site
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
When you type a URL, your device uses DNS to map the domain name to an IP address.

Then it connects and requests resources using HTTP/HTTPS.

Caching and CDNs make this faster.

Understanding this pipeline helps you diagnose common “site not found” or slow-load issues.

sampleIdeas.name: Cookies and tracking: what actually happens
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Cookies can store useful session state (like a login) but can also be used for tracking.

Third-party cookies and embedded scripts can link behavior across sites.

Modern browsers and laws increasingly limit cross-site tracking.

You can reduce tracking by restricting permissions, clearing cookies, and using privacy settings.

sampleIdeas.name: 2FA and password hygiene that works
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Unique strong passwords stop credential stuffing. A password manager makes this practical.

2FA adds a second barrier so stolen passwords alone aren’t enough.

Prefer app-based or device-prompt 2FA over SMS when possible.

Security is about reducing risk, not perfection.

sampleIdeas.name: How to spot phishing quickly
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Phishing relies on urgency and impersonation. Look for mismatched domains, unexpected attachments, and pressure tactics.

Verify by navigating independently (type the known site) rather than clicking links.

Never share one-time codes.

Report suspicious messages to your provider or organization.

name: STEM Algebra & Functions
description: Essential algebra and functions for STEM: graphs, equations, quadratics, exponentials, and modeling.

cards.back: A function assigns each input exactly one output.

cards.front: What is the domain of a function?
cards.back: The set of all allowed input values for the function.

cards.front: What is the range of a function?
cards.back: The set of outputs the function can produce.
A linear function with slope m and y-intercept b.

cards.front: What does the slope of a line measure?
cards.back: The rate of change: rise over run.

cards.front: How do you find the y-intercept from an equation?
cards.back: Set x=0 and solve for y.

cards.front: What is a quadratic function’s standard form?
cards.back: f(x)=ax^2+bx+c, where a≠0.

cards.front: What does the discriminant b^2-4ac tell you?
cards.back: It indicates the number/type of real roots of a quadratic.

cards.front: What does it mean to factor a polynomial?
cards.back: Rewrite it as a product of simpler polynomials.

cards.front: What is an exponent rule for multiplying same bases?
cards.back: a^m·a^n=a^(m+n).

cards.front: What is an exponent rule for dividing same bases?

cards.back: log_b(x)=y means b^y=x.

cards.front: What is a system of linear equations?
cards.back: Two or more linear equations solved simultaneously.

cards.front: What does it mean if two lines are parallel?
cards.back: They have equal slopes and never intersect.

cards.front: What does it mean if two lines are perpendicular?
cards.back: Their slopes multiply to −1 (for non-vertical lines).
A linear relationship passing through the origin (y=kx).
A comparison of two quantities by division.
A ratio out of 100.

cards.front: What is the purpose of units in algebra problems?
cards.back: Units help check if an equation or result makes physical sense.
A statement comparing quantities using <, ≤, >, or ≥.

cards.front: How do inequalities change when multiplied by a negative?
cards.back: The inequality sign reverses direction.
A function defined by different rules on different intervals.

cards.front: What is a function’s average rate of change on [a,b]?

cards.back: It reverses inputs and outputs: f^{-1}(y)=x if f(x)=y.
It must be one-to-one (passes the horizontal line test).
y varies directly with x: y=kx.

cards.front: What is an exponential growth model?
cards.back: A model like y=a·b^x with b>1.
A model like y=a·b^x with 0<b<1.

cards.front: What is the meaning of “solve an equation”?
cards.back: Find all values that make the equation true.

cards.front: What is a linear approximation idea?
cards.back: Use a tangent line to approximate a function near a point.

sampleIdeas.name: Functions: domain, range, and graphs
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A function is a rule that assigns each input exactly one output. The domain is the set of allowed inputs; the range is the set of possible outputs.

Graphing is a visual way to see how outputs change as inputs change. A vertical line test checks whether a graph represents a function.

When solving real problems, always interpret domain restrictions (like time ≥ 0 or nonnegative lengths).

Thinking in terms of inputs/outputs makes many word problems simpler.

sampleIdeas.name: Linear functions and slope as rate of change
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Linear functions model constant rate of change. In f(x)=mx+b, m is the slope and b is the starting value (intercept).

Slope can be interpreted as “units of output per unit of input,” which connects directly to speed, cost per item, or growth per year.

Two-point form and point-slope form help build an equation from data.

Checking units and interpreting the intercept prevents common mistakes.

sampleIdeas.name: Quadratics: roots, vertex, and meaning
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Quadratic functions appear in projectile motion, optimization, and area problems. The roots are x-values where the graph crosses the x-axis.

The vertex is the maximum or minimum point, depending on whether the parabola opens up or down.

The discriminant b^2−4ac predicts how many real roots exist.

Different forms (standard, factored, vertex form) highlight different features.

sampleIdeas.name: Exponents and logarithms: inverse ideas
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Exponents model repeated multiplication and rapid growth/decay. Logarithms are the inverse operation: log_b(x)=y means b^y=x.

Log rules simplify multiplication into addition and division into subtraction, which is why logs appear in scientific formulas.

Understanding “inverse” helps with solving exponential equations.

Always track base and domain restrictions (x>0 for real logs).

sampleIdeas.name: Modeling with equations: sanity checks
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A model is a simplified equation that captures a relationship. Good modeling uses variables with clear meanings and units.

Before solving, estimate what a reasonable answer should look like. After solving, check units and plug the solution back into the original relationship.

This workflow catches many errors.

In STEM, modeling is often more important than memorizing formulas.

sampleIdeas.name: Systems of equations: intersection viewpoint
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A system of equations represents multiple conditions that must be true at the same time. Graphically, solutions are intersections.

You can solve with substitution, elimination, or graphing, depending on the context.

In real applications (mixing, pricing, physics constraints), defining variables clearly matters more than the method.

Check whether a solution is unique, infinite (same line), or none (parallel).

sampleIdeas.name: Inequalities and intervals
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Inequalities describe ranges of values rather than a single value. Solutions are often written in interval notation.

A key rule: multiplying or dividing by a negative number flips the inequality sign.

Graphing inequalities on a number line gives a clear picture.

In STEM contexts, inequalities encode constraints (like safety limits or feasible designs).

sampleIdeas.name: Rates of change: from algebra to calculus
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Average rate of change is the slope between two points: (f(b)−f(a))/(b−a). This is a stepping stone to derivatives.

When you shrink the interval, average rate of change approaches instantaneous rate of change.

This idea connects algebraic slopes to physical speed and growth rates.

It’s one of the most important bridges in STEM learning.

sampleIdeas.name: Common algebra mistakes and how to avoid them
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Most algebra mistakes come from skipping steps: distributing incorrectly, dropping negative signs, or mixing up order of operations.

Write intermediate steps, especially when you move terms across an equals sign.

Use quick checks: plug in simple numbers, test units, or graph to verify behavior.

Accuracy first; speed comes later.

sampleIdeas.name: Practice plan: spaced repetition for math
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Math sticks when practice is spaced and mixed. Instead of doing 20 similar problems in a row, mix topics.

Use short daily sessions and track error types. Make flashcards for rules you repeatedly miss.

After solving, explain the reasoning in one sentence: this builds transfer.

Consistency beats marathon sessions.

name: STEM Biology: Cells & Genetics
description: Cell basics, DNA, gene expression, cell division, and core genetics for STEM learners.

cards.back: All living things are made of cells; cells are the basic unit of life; cells come from pre-existing cells.

cards.front: What is the difference between prokaryotes and eukaryotes?
cards.back: Prokaryotes lack a nucleus; eukaryotes have a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles.
DNA stores genetic information used to build and regulate an organism.
A segment of DNA that encodes a functional product (often a protein).
A packaged DNA molecule with associated proteins.
Making RNA from a DNA template.
Building a protein from an mRNA sequence.
A change in DNA sequence that can affect function.
Differential survival and reproduction of individuals with heritable traits.
Cell division producing two genetically identical daughter cells.
Cell division producing gametes with half the chromosome number.
An allele expressed in the phenotype when present in one copy.
An allele expressed only when two copies are present (in simple Mendelian cases).
Maintaining stable internal conditions despite external changes.
A biological catalyst that speeds up reactions by lowering activation energy.
ATP is a cellular energy currency used to power processes.

cards.front: What is a membrane’s main role?
cards.back: It controls what enters and leaves the cell, maintaining internal conditions.
Net movement from high to low concentration.
Diffusion of water across a semipermeable membrane.
Observable traits resulting from genes and environment.

sampleIdeas.name: A tour of the cell: organelles as “departments”
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Cells are the basic unit of life, and eukaryotic cells have specialized compartments (organelles).

The nucleus stores DNA, mitochondria produce ATP, and membranes regulate transport.

Thinking of organelles as departments in a city helps you remember roles.

Modern biology builds on this structure-function logic.

sampleIdeas.name: DNA → RNA → Protein: the central dogma
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Genetic information flows from DNA to RNA (transcription) and from RNA to protein (translation).

Proteins do much of the functional work in cells: enzymes, structures, transport, and signaling.

Mutations can change protein function, sometimes harmful, sometimes neutral, sometimes beneficial.

This framework links genetics to traits.

sampleIdeas.name: Mitosis vs meiosis: why they exist
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Mitosis creates identical cells for growth and repair. Meiosis creates gametes with half the chromosomes.

Meiosis also increases genetic variation through recombination and independent assortment.

Knowing which process applies explains many inheritance patterns.

Use simple diagrams to track chromosome count.

sampleIdeas.name: Mendelian genetics: the simplest inheritance model
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Mendel’s model treats traits as controlled by alleles, where dominant alleles can mask recessive alleles.

Punnett squares help predict genotype proportions under simple assumptions.

Real genetics often includes multiple genes, incomplete dominance, and environment effects.

Start simple, then expand.

sampleIdeas.name: Homeostasis: stability through feedback
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Homeostasis keeps variables like temperature and blood sugar in ranges that support life.

Negative feedback loops counteract change; positive feedback amplifies change in special cases.

Understanding feedback prevents oversimplified health claims.

It’s a unifying principle across physiology.

sampleIdeas.name: Natural selection: mechanism, not a slogan
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Natural selection requires variation, heritability, and differential reproductive success.

It does not “aim” for perfection; it filters traits that work better in a given environment.

This explains adaptation and why populations change over time.

Evolution is central to modern biology.

sampleIdeas.name: Enzymes: why chemistry works in living cells
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Enzymes speed up reactions by lowering activation energy. They don’t change equilibrium; they change speed.

Temperature and pH can affect enzyme structure and function.

This explains why biological systems have narrow operating ranges.

It’s a bridge between chemistry and biology.

sampleIdeas.name: Membranes and transport
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Cell membranes are lipid bilayers with proteins that control transport.

Diffusion moves particles down gradients; active transport uses energy.

Osmosis explains water movement and many real phenomena (like plant turgor).

Transport concepts show up everywhere in physiology.

sampleIdeas.name: Genetics in real life: from traits to disease risk
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Many traits are polygenic and influenced by environment. Single-gene traits exist but are less common.

Genetics can affect disease risk, but it is not destiny.

Understanding this prevents deterministic thinking and misinformation.

Use reputable sources for health genetics claims.

sampleIdeas.name: Practice plan: build diagrams and vocabulary
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Biology sticks when you draw processes: DNA replication, transcription, cell division.

Use flashcards for vocabulary, but connect words to diagrams.

Review frequently with spaced repetition.

Explain each process in your own words to test understanding.

name: STEM Calculus Foundations
description: Limits, derivatives, and integrals with the intuition needed for STEM problem-solving.

cards.back: A limit describes what a function approaches as the input approaches a value.

cards.front: What does it mean if lim_{x→a} f(x) exists?
cards.back: The left-hand and right-hand limits both exist and are equal.

cards.front: What is continuity at a point a?
cards.back: f(a) is defined, the limit at a exists, and it equals f(a).
The derivative is the instantaneous rate of change of a function.

cards.front: How is derivative related to slope?
cards.back: It is the slope of the tangent line to the graph at a point.

cards.front: What does the notation f'(x) represent?
cards.back: The derivative of f with respect to x.
(fg)'=f'g+fg'.
An integral accumulates quantities; geometrically it relates to area under a curve.

cards.front: What does the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus connect?
cards.back: It links differentiation and integration as inverse processes.
A number representing accumulated quantity over an interval.
A family of antiderivatives plus a constant C.
A point where f'(x)=0 or f' is undefined.

cards.front: How do you classify local maxima/minima?
cards.back: Using sign changes of f' or the second derivative test.

cards.front: What is the mean value theorem (idea)?
cards.back: If f is continuous and differentiable, some tangent slope equals average slope.

cards.front: What is a Taylor approximation intuition?
cards.back: Approximate a function near a point using a polynomial.

cards.front: What does “units” mean for a derivative?
cards.back: Units of output per unit of input.
A line the function approaches but may not reach.
An integral with infinite limits or unbounded integrand evaluated as a limit.
Using derivatives to find maxima/minima under constraints.

sampleIdeas.name: Limits: the language of “approach”
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Limits formalize the idea of getting arbitrarily close to a value. They handle cases where direct substitution fails.

Left-hand and right-hand limits must agree for the limit to exist.

Limits are the foundation for continuity, derivatives, and integrals.

A strong intuition comes from graphs and numerical tables.

sampleIdeas.name: Derivatives as rate of change in the real world
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The derivative models instantaneous change: speed is the derivative of position, and marginal cost is the derivative of cost.

The tangent slope viewpoint helps visualize sensitivity.

Rules (product/chain) automate derivative computation, but interpretation is the real payoff.

Always track units: it prevents nonsense answers.

sampleIdeas.name: Integration as accumulation
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Integration adds up tiny contributions. That’s why it appears in distance from velocity, mass from density, and total probability from a density function.

The definite integral has units: (units of f)×(units of x).

The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus connects integrals to antiderivatives.

Practice translating word problems into “accumulate over an interval.”

sampleIdeas.name: Continuity: when “no jumps” really matters
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A function is continuous at a point if the limit exists and equals the value. This simple idea enables powerful theorems.

Continuity ensures that intermediate values are hit, which underlies many existence proofs.

Graphing helps: removable discontinuities, jumps, and vertical asymptotes behave differently.

In modeling, discontinuities often signal missing assumptions.

sampleIdeas.name: Optimization workflow
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Optimization problems follow a pattern: define a quantity to optimize, express it as a function of one variable using constraints, then differentiate.

Critical points plus endpoints are the candidates.

Interpret the result back in the original context, including units.

This is one of the most common calculus applications in engineering and economics.

sampleIdeas.name: Chain rule intuition: nested changes
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The chain rule handles “a change that causes a change.” If y depends on u and u depends on x, then y changes with x through u.

This is common in physics (temperature depends on time, time depends on position in a moving frame) and in machine learning.

Keeping track of intermediate variables makes derivations cleaner.

Draw dependency arrows to avoid mistakes.

sampleIdeas.name: Common calculus mistakes
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Common errors include forgetting the chain rule, dropping constants, and confusing average vs instantaneous change.

Write derivatives step-by-step, then simplify.

Check with a quick graphing intuition: does the sign and magnitude make sense?

Treat calculus as structured reasoning, not just symbol pushing.

sampleIdeas.name: Second derivative: curvature and acceleration
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The second derivative measures how the first derivative changes. In motion, it’s acceleration.

It also describes concavity: whether a curve bends up or down.

Concavity helps classify maxima/minima and understand stability.

Look for inflection points where concavity changes.

sampleIdeas.name: Definite integrals: area vs signed area
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A definite integral gives signed area: regions below the x-axis subtract.

If you need total area, integrate absolute value or split intervals at zeros.

This distinction matters in displacement vs distance problems.

Drawing a quick sketch prevents sign mistakes.

sampleIdeas.name: Practice plan: mixed review
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
To retain calculus, mix problem types: limits, derivatives, applications, and integrals.

Use spaced repetition for key rules and common forms.

After each problem, write the interpretation (units, meaning) in one sentence.

This builds transfer beyond exam-style questions.

name: STEM Chemistry Essentials
description: Atoms, the periodic table, bonding, reactions, and basic stoichiometry for STEM learners.

cards.back: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains its chemical identity.
The number of protons in the nucleus.
A mole is 6.022×10^23 entities (Avogadro’s number).
Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.
A measure of how strongly an atom attracts bonding electrons.
A bond formed by electron transfer and electrostatic attraction between ions.
A bond where atoms share electron pairs.

cards.front: What is a polar covalent bond?
cards.back: A covalent bond with unequal sharing due to electronegativity differences.

cards.front: What is a chemical reaction equation?
cards.back: A symbolic representation of reactants transforming into products with conserved atoms.

cards.front: What does it mean to balance an equation?
cards.back: Adjust coefficients so each element has the same count on both sides.
Quantitative relationships between reactants and products using balanced equations.
A logarithmic measure of hydrogen ion activity; lower pH is more acidic.
A substance that donates a proton (H+) in the Brønsted–Lowry model.
A substance that accepts a proton (H+) in the Brønsted–Lowry model.

cards.front: What is conservation of mass in reactions?
cards.back: Total mass of reactants equals total mass of products in a closed system.

cards.front: What is the periodic table used for?
cards.back: It organizes elements by atomic number and reveals patterns in properties.
An electron in the outermost shell involved in bonding.
A homogeneous mixture of solute dissolved in solvent.
Moles of solute per liter of solution.
A measure related to average kinetic energy of particles.

sampleIdeas.name: Reading the periodic table for patterns
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The periodic table organizes elements by atomic number, grouping elements with similar valence structures.

Periods relate to electron shells; groups relate to valence electrons, which helps predict bonding and reactivity.

You don’t need to memorize everything—learn the big regions (alkali metals, halogens, noble gases) and trends.

This turns the table into a reasoning tool rather than a poster.

sampleIdeas.name: Bonding: why atoms form molecules
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Atoms bond to reach more stable electron configurations. Ionic bonding involves electron transfer; covalent bonding involves sharing.

Electronegativity differences explain polarity, which explains properties like solubility and boiling point.

Lewis structures are a useful first model.

As you advance, you refine the model with orbitals and molecular geometry.

sampleIdeas.name: Stoichiometry: the language of quantities
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Stoichiometry uses balanced equations to convert between moles of reactants and products.

The key is the mole ratio from coefficients.

Always write units at every step; it prevents “magic-number” mistakes.

Limiting reactants determine how much product can form.

sampleIdeas.name: Acids, bases, and pH without confusion
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
In the Brønsted–Lowry model, acids donate H+ and bases accept H+. pH is a logarithmic scale, so each unit is a tenfold change.

Strong acids/bases dissociate more completely, but concentration also matters.

Buffers resist pH changes, which is crucial in biology.

A few anchor points (pH 7 neutral) help build intuition.

sampleIdeas.name: Matter, mixtures, and solutions
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A solution is a homogeneous mixture, and concentration measures “how much solute per amount of solution.”

Solubility depends on temperature and interactions between molecules (polarity).

Distinguish mass percent, molarity, and ppm based on context.

Label units carefully to avoid common conversion errors.

sampleIdeas.name: Core chemistry safety: lab mindset
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Chemistry is powerful, so safety rules matter: assume unknowns are hazardous, avoid ingestion/inhalation, and use PPE when appropriate.

Understanding labels and SDS sheets is part of scientific literacy.

Even outside the lab, these habits translate to safe household chemical use.

Always follow local safety guidance and supervision in lab settings.

sampleIdeas.name: Conservation laws in chemistry
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Balancing equations reflects conservation of atoms. In closed systems, mass is conserved.

Charge conservation matters in redox reactions.

These conservation ideas let you check your work quickly.

If atoms or charge don’t match, something is wrong.

sampleIdeas.name: Trends: atomic radius and ionization energy
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Periodic trends follow electron structure: atomic radius tends to decrease across a period and increase down a group.

Ionization energy often increases across a period as atoms hold electrons more tightly.

Memorize the direction, then explain it with shielding and nuclear charge.

Explanations matter more than recall.

sampleIdeas.name: Chemistry problem-solving workflow
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Start by identifying what is given and what is asked. Convert to moles early when stoichiometry is involved.

Write balanced equations before plugging numbers.

Track units line-by-line.

Finish with a reasonableness check: order of magnitude and limiting case.

sampleIdeas.name: Practice plan: spaced repetition for equations and concepts
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Chemistry rewards frequent short practice. Use flashcards for definitions and trend directions.

Use mixed problem sets for stoichiometry, concentration, and pH.

Review your mistakes weekly.

This builds durable intuition rather than temporary memorization.

name: STEM Computer Science Foundations
description: Programming and CS essentials: algorithms, data structures, efficiency, debugging, and APIs.

cards.back: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or performing a computation.

cards.front: What is a variable in programming?
cards.back: A named reference to a value that can change during execution.
A reusable block of code that takes inputs and returns an output (or performs an action).
A control structure that chooses behavior based on a boolean condition (if/else).
A structure that repeats a block of code while a condition holds or for a set count.
A way to organize and store data so operations are efficient.
An ordered collection of items accessible by index.
A key-value structure designed for fast lookup by key.
A way to describe how runtime or memory grows with input size.
Runtime grows linearly with the input size n.

cards.front: What does O(log n) often indicate?
cards.back: Algorithms that repeatedly halve the problem size, like binary search.
A search that repeatedly halves a sorted range to find a target.
An error in code that causes incorrect or unexpected behavior.
The process of finding and fixing bugs.

cards.front: What is version control (e.g., Git) for?
cards.back: Tracking code changes over time and enabling collaboration.
A defined interface that lets software components communicate.

cards.front: What is the difference between compiler and interpreter?
cards.back: A compiler translates code ahead of time; an interpreter executes code step-by-step.
A data type with two values: true or false.
A function calling itself on smaller subproblems until a base case.

cards.front: Why do we care about data types?
cards.back: They determine what operations are valid and how data is stored.

sampleIdeas.name: Programming building blocks: variables, conditionals, loops
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Most programs are built from a few primitives: storing values (variables), choosing actions (conditionals), and repeating work (loops).

Understanding these building blocks makes any language easier.

Focus on logic first; syntax differences are secondary.

Practice by writing small programs that manipulate input and produce output.

sampleIdeas.name: Algorithms: the heart of computing
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
An algorithm is a recipe for computation. Different algorithms can solve the same problem with different efficiency.

Big-O notation describes how resource use grows with input size.

This helps you choose approaches that scale.

Efficiency is often more important than micro-optimizations.

sampleIdeas.name: Data structures: choosing the right container
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Data structures trade off speed and memory. Arrays are simple; hash maps support fast lookup; trees support ordered operations.

Choosing the right structure often simplifies the algorithm.

Start with arrays and dictionaries, then learn stacks/queues and trees.

Examples beat memorization: implement small versions yourself.

sampleIdeas.name: Debugging mindset: isolate, test, fix
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Debugging is a skill: reproduce the issue, reduce it to the smallest failing case, and test hypotheses.

Use print/log statements or a debugger to inspect state.

Write tests for the bug so it doesn’t return.

This is how professionals work day-to-day.

sampleIdeas.name: APIs: how software connects
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
APIs define how programs communicate: input formats, output formats, and allowed operations.

In web apps, APIs often use HTTP and JSON.

Understanding APIs makes you productive quickly.

Read docs carefully: endpoints, authentication, and rate limits.

sampleIdeas.name: Version control: your safety net
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Version control tracks changes so you can revert mistakes and collaborate.

Commit small, meaningful changes with messages that explain intent.

Branches allow experimentation without breaking main code.

This is foundational for modern software teams.

sampleIdeas.name: Binary search and invariants
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Binary search works on sorted data by maintaining an invariant: the target is in a shrinking interval.

Each step halves the search space, giving O(log n) time.

The hard part is getting boundaries right.

Trace on paper with small arrays to build confidence.

sampleIdeas.name: Big-O intuition with examples
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Big-O compares growth rates. O(1) is constant, O(n) is linear, O(n^2) is quadratic.

For large inputs, growth rate dominates.

Use concrete examples (searching, sorting) to make it real.

This helps you reason without measuring every time.

sampleIdeas.name: Recursion: when self-similarity helps
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Recursion solves a problem by solving smaller versions until a base case.

It’s natural for trees and divide-and-conquer algorithms.

Always define a base case and ensure progress toward it.

Practice with factorial, Fibonacci (with memoization), and tree traversals.

sampleIdeas.name: Learning plan: build small projects
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The fastest way to learn programming is to build small projects: a calculator, a quiz app, a simple scraper.

Each project teaches debugging, I/O, and structuring code.

Use spaced repetition for concepts you forget (syntax, operators).

Progress comes from consistent practice, not perfect resources.

name: STEM Physics: Mechanics Essentials
description: Core mechanics for STEM: Newton’s laws, energy, momentum, and circular motion.

cards.back: An object keeps its velocity unless acted on by a net external force.
Net force equals mass times acceleration: F=ma.
For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force.
The rate of change of velocity with time.
The gravitational force on a mass: W=mg.
A force resisting relative motion between surfaces in contact.
Momentum is mass times velocity: p=mv.
Impulse equals change in momentum: J=Δp.
Work is energy transferred by force through displacement: W=F·d·cosθ.
Kinetic energy is ½mv^2.

cards.front: What is gravitational potential energy near Earth?
cards.back: U=mgh (relative to a reference height).
Power is the rate of doing work: P=W/t.
Energy changes form but total energy in a closed system remains constant.

cards.front: What is the difference between speed and velocity?
cards.back: Speed is magnitude only; velocity includes direction.
Acceleration toward the center of circular motion: a=v^2/r.
A diagram showing all external forces acting on an object.
Net force equals zero, so acceleration is zero.
Pressure is force per area: P=F/A.
Density is mass per volume: ρ=m/V.
Spring force is proportional to displacement: F=kx (direction opposite stretch).

sampleIdeas.name: Newton’s laws: the core model of motion
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Newton’s laws connect forces to motion. The key is net force: forces can cancel or add.

Free-body diagrams help you track forces systematically.

Many problems become simple once you identify the system and the external forces.

Always check units and directions.

sampleIdeas.name: Work and energy: a second way to solve motion
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Work-energy methods can solve motion without tracking acceleration at every moment.

If only conservative forces act, mechanical energy is conserved.

This is powerful for ramps, springs, and gravity problems.

Choose the method (forces vs energy) that makes the problem simplest.

sampleIdeas.name: Momentum and collisions
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Momentum is conserved in isolated systems, even when kinetic energy is not.

Impulse connects force over time to momentum change.

Elastic vs inelastic collisions differ in whether kinetic energy is conserved.

Drawing before/after diagrams prevents sign mistakes.

sampleIdeas.name: Circular motion and centripetal force
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Circular motion requires inward acceleration a=v^2/r.

The “centripetal force” is not a new type of force; it’s the net inward force required.

Common sources are tension, friction, or gravity.

Separating radial and tangential directions clarifies equations.

sampleIdeas.name: Common mechanics pitfalls
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
The most frequent mistakes are mixing up mass vs weight, forgetting direction signs, and skipping free-body diagrams.

Write vector components when needed.

Use limiting cases: if friction → 0 or mass doubles, should the result change in the expected way?

These checks catch errors fast.

sampleIdeas.name: Units and dimensional analysis
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Dimensional analysis checks whether an equation can be correct by comparing units.

In mechanics, it’s an instant error detector.

For example, energy must have units of joules (kg·m^2/s^2).

If units don’t match, the formula is wrong or incomplete.

sampleIdeas.name: Energy diagrams and reference levels
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Potential energy depends on the reference level you choose; only differences matter.

Energy bar charts and diagrams help track transformations.

This approach avoids algebraic sign confusion.

It’s especially useful in multi-step problems.

sampleIdeas.name: Friction: models and limits
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Friction is modeled as proportional to normal force in many intro problems, but it’s an approximation.

Static friction adjusts up to a maximum; kinetic friction is often lower.

Knowing which regime applies is critical.

Real surfaces can behave differently, but the model is useful for basics.

sampleIdeas.name: Problem-solving workflow for physics
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Translate words into a sketch, choose a system, draw a free-body diagram, then write equations.

Solve symbolically before plugging numbers.

Check units and reasonableness (order of magnitude).

This is how you build reliable intuition.

sampleIdeas.name: Practice plan: mixed problems + spaced review
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Alternate forces, energy, and momentum problems so you learn when each tool applies.

Turn common formulas into flashcards, but always include meaning and units.

Review errors weekly: the fastest improvement comes from patterning your mistakes.

Consistency beats cramming.

name: STEM Probability & Statistics
description: Probability and statistics essentials: distributions, sampling, inference, and correlation vs causation.

cards.front: What is a population in statistics?
cards.back: The entire set of individuals or items you want to study.
A subset of the population used to estimate characteristics.
A numerical value describing a population (often unknown).
A numerical value computed from a sample.
The arithmetic average of data values.
The middle value when data are ordered.
A measure of typical spread around the mean.
A symmetric bell-shaped distribution characterized by mean and standard deviation.
A measure of likelihood, from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
Probability of A given B: P(A|B).
Events are independent if P(A|B)=P(A).
A weighted average outcome using probabilities.
A measure of association between variables, not necessarily causation.
Because a third factor (confounder) or reverse causality may explain the association.
A measure of how surprising the data are if a null hypothesis were true.
A result is statistically significant if it’s unlikely under the null by a chosen threshold.
A range of plausible values for a population parameter based on sample data.
When the sample is not representative of the population, skewing conclusions.
A method to model the relationship between variables, often with a best-fit line.

cards.front: What is the law of large numbers?
cards.back: As sample size increases, sample averages tend to approach the expected value.

sampleIdeas.name: Correlation vs causation (and confounders)
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Correlation measures association, but it doesn’t tell you why two variables move together.

A confounder can create a correlation without direct causation, and causation can run in the opposite direction.

To argue causation, you need stronger designs: randomized experiments, natural experiments, or careful causal inference.

This principle protects you from misleading headlines.

sampleIdeas.name: Distributions and variability
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Two datasets can have the same average but very different spread. Standard deviation measures typical distance from the mean.

Visualizing distributions (histograms, box plots) reveals patterns averages hide.

Normal distributions are common, but not universal.

Always look at shape before interpreting statistics.

sampleIdeas.name: Sampling and bias: why representativeness matters
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Statistical conclusions depend on how data are collected. A biased sample can produce precise but wrong results.

Random sampling reduces bias, but practical constraints often introduce it.

Learn to ask: Who is missing? How were they selected?

This is core for scientific and media literacy.

sampleIdeas.name: Confidence intervals (intuition)
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A confidence interval is a method that produces ranges which, under repeated sampling, contain the true parameter a known fraction of the time.

It’s not a probability that the parameter is in the interval; it’s about the procedure.

Intervals communicate uncertainty better than a single point estimate.

They’re essential for honest interpretation.

sampleIdeas.name: p-values and hypothesis testing (high-level)
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A p-value quantifies how unusual the observed data would be if a null hypothesis were true.

A small p-value suggests the data are inconsistent with the null, but it does not measure effect size or practical importance.

Multiple testing and p-hacking can mislead.

Prefer effect sizes and confidence intervals when possible.

sampleIdeas.name: Expected value and real decisions
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Expected value is the long-run average outcome, useful for games, risk, and cost-benefit thinking.

It helps you evaluate lotteries, insurance, and investment risk (at a basic level).

But variability and risk tolerance also matter.

Always interpret EV in context.

sampleIdeas.name: Regression basics: trends and residuals
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Regression models relationships, often with a best-fit line. Residuals show what the model misses.

A good fit does not prove causation.

Check assumptions and watch for outliers.

Use regression as a descriptive tool unless causal design supports more.
